Award.AwardTitle: MRI: Acquisition of a High Performance CPU-GPU Computer Cluster for Scientific Computing at U Sciences
Award.AbstractNarration:
With this award from the Major Research Instrumentation Program, Professor Preston Moore from University of the Sciences in Philadelphia and colleagues Michael Bruist, Randy Zauhar, Vojislava Pophristic and Zhijun Li will acquire a high performance CPU-GPU computer cluster. The proposal is aimed at enhancing research training and education at all levels, especially in areas such as (a) coarse grain molecular dynamics models to investigate complex interfacial systems such as solid/liquid interface and protein/lipid systems; (b) methodology and parameters for the prediction of arylamide foldamer structure to aid the design of foldamers; (c) molecular database and web accessible interface for computer aided drug design (CADD); (d) homology modeling of membrane proteins with low sequence identity; and (e) noncanonical base pairs in RNA loops and the role of conformational changes in protein-DNA complexes.

Computer systems and clusters of computers are used by chemists and biochemists to investigate reactions and the properties of chemicals and materials using theoretical models and programs. The computer calculations are used, often along with experimental data, to model and better understand many types of complex chemical and biological phenomena. They are also used to predict results and guide experiments. This resource will be used in research and in course work by undergraduate and graduate students as well as faculty training them in computational chemistry methodology with a modern computer system. Collaborations with local industries such as Y-Carbon will enhance the manufacturing of nanomaterials by design, which is essential to improving the U.S. manufacturing base of advanced materials. In addition, outreach programs for Philadelphia high schools and the community, which is predominately composed of underrepresented groups, will also use the cluster.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The main goal of the NSF award # 1229564 titled “MRI: Acquisition of a High Performance CPU-GPU Computer Cluster for Scientific Computing at USciences” was to acquire a high performance CPU-GPU computer cluster within the West Center for Computational Chemistry and Drug Design (West Center) at the University of the Sciences in Philadelphia (USciences).  The West Center serves as a centralized research high performance computing facility at USciences, and became more capable, efficient, and effective in carrying out computational research for the scientific community at USciences due to NSF award# 1229564. The cluster enabled and continues to enable the West Center to advance the scientific training of students at all levels throughout USciences and beyond. Researchers associated with the West Center were able to perform calculations much faster, and critically were able to investigate problems that were not feasible with the previous computational power available at USciences.

To date the cluster has been utilized for scientific discoveries resulting in over 20 peer reviewed publications, and we expect many more in the coming years.  We highlight some outcomes of the research at the end of this document.  Beyond generating data, the cluster provides many opportunities for training and professional development for the current and next generation of scientist.  In particular, the cluster has been utilized by high-school student, undergraduates, graduate students, post-doctoral fellows and professors.  To date we have trained graduate students not only on the use but also the maintenance (hardware and software) of high performance computer clusters.  Six graduate students were able to use the cluster to accelerate their simulations and research which helped  them become independent researchers and obtained their PhDs.  A number of USciences undergraduate students have received training and gained research experience in computational chemistry methods utilizing the cluster.  While manly used for research the cluster is also used for teaching, where each semester the undergraduate physical chemistry classes (thermo/kinetics and quantum) utilize the cluster for undergraduate projects, exposing them to modern computer clusters and computational techniques.  Further, the cluster has provided the opportunity for high school students to gained experience in QM and MD methods, as well as scientific writing and  presentation. Once example, is the Physician Scientist Training Program (PSTP), STEMPREP Project  for minority high school students.

The PI and associated faculty, post-doctoral fellows, graduate and undergraduate students have also given numerous invited talks and poster presentations at local, regional, and national scientific meetings.  Below are selected scientific projects which highlight the research enable by the cluster, all of which have been published or submitted to peer reviewed journals for publication:

Example Outcomes:

(1) We use molecular dynamics (MD) simulations to study lipid bilayer membranes. Specifically, we studied the structure and  dynamics of transmembrane (TM) proteins that are known to form  ion-channels. The structural and dynamic properties of proteins, structural  perturbation of lipids surrounding the TM protein and water movement through  the transmembrane channel have been analyzed.  We have also carried out a molecular dynamics study of amphipathic drug  interactions with the lipid bilayers and vesicles.

(2) We are studying arylamide foldamers.  Our goal is to develop a methodology and an associated library that will allow  for rational design of arylamide foldamers.   We have carried out a molecular dynamics simulations of the “apple peel” like  arylamide foldamers that can encapsulate small ligands.  In collaboration with Ivan Huc’s group in France, whose  research focuses on design, synthesis and applications of arylamide oligomers.  We have used metadynamics, an enhanced sampling MD method, to obtain  foldamer folding-unfolding free energy profiles.

(3) We have utilized the virtual screening tool Shape Signatures to screen a  large database for agents targeting the type IIA bacterial topoisomerase, DNA  Gyrase, an essential enzyme involved in bacterial replication, through the  ATP-dependent supercoiling of DNA.

(4) We develop computational techniques for  structure modeling of helical membrane proteins. Specifically, we improve the  accuracy of homology modeling through multiple-template derived conserved  inter-residue interactions and restrained simulated annealing.

(5) We have  simulated numerous versions of the sarcin/ricin RNA motifs. Adaptively biased molecular dynamics simulations are used to compare the  stability and the unfolding pathways to G/C-rich and A/U-rich RNA A-form  helices. The richness of simulation data has created the need for more detailed  physical probing of the stacking of bases.

The results from the studies conducted utilizing the cluster have already had a broad and significant impact in a wide number of areas and fields, including chemistry, biochemistry, material science, pharmaceutics, physics, biology, and medicine. We expect more discoveries as faculty, staff and students continue to utilize the cluster obtain from the NSF grant #1229564.
